Pride Events in New York: Here’s How to Celebrate
=================================================

A month of parades, protests, dance parties and drag shows galore.

*   Share full article 
*    

![Image 1: A man holding a rainbow flag stands on the shoulders of two other people, with rainbow confetti floating in the air. ](https://static01.nyt.com/images/2025/05/30/multimedia/29pride-events-roundup-fhpq/29pride-events-roundup-fhpq-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&disable=upscale)

New York City’s official Pride march returns to Greenwich Village on June 29.Credit...Graham Dickie/The New York Times

[![Image 2: Erik Piepenburg](https://static01.nyt.com/images/2022/02/02/reader-center/author-erik-piepenburg/author-erik-piepenburg-thumbLarge.png)](https://www.nytimes.com/by/erik-piepenburg)

By [Erik Piepenburg](https://www.nytimes.com/by/erik-piepenburg)

May 29, 2025

On June 29, New York City’s official Pride march starts around 11 a.m. under the defiantly political theme “Rise Up: Pride in Protest.” Karine Jean-Pierre, the former press secretary in the Biden-Harris administration, is one of the grand marshals. [PrideFest](https://www.nycpride.org/event/pridefest), the annual street fair featuring food and activities for all ages, also returns.

Pre-party the day before at the South Street Seaport Museum with [Youth Pride](https://www.nycpride.org/event/youth-pride) and at the [NYC Dyke March](https://www.nycdykemarch.com/) — a “protest march, not a parade,” according to the organizers — that steps off from Bryant Park at 5 p.m.

Other Pride Month parades and festivals include: [Staten Island](https://www.pridecentersi.org/pride-festival-2025) (May 31); [Asbury Park, N.J.](https://jerseypride.org/) (June 1); [Queens](https://newqueenspride.org/) (June 1); [Westchester County, N.Y.](https://www.loftgaycenter.org/westchester_pride_hosted_by_the_loft) (June 1); [Long Island](https://lipride.org/) (June 8); [Woodstock, N.Y.](https://www.woodstocknypride.org/parade-2025) (June 8); [Brooklyn](https://brooklynpride.org/) (June 14); [Hudson, N.Y.](https://www.outhudsonny.com/) (June 21); [the Bronx](https://cbo.io/app/public/bidapp/bronxpridefestival) (June 21); and [Harlem](https://harlempride.org/) (June 28).

With so many dance-till-you-drop parties taking place over Pride weekend, now might be a good idea to take a Monday off. Two of the more popular ones are the [Brut Party](https://brutparty.com/event/nyc-pride-2025/) in Times Square (June 27), for the leather-and-harness set, and the 25th annual [Alegria](https://www.ricsenapresents.com/events/alegria-pride-2025) (June 29), which begins at 4:30 p.m. at Avant Gardner in Brooklyn and ends 24 hours later with Sunrise, a chill rooftop comedown.

[SKIP ADVERTISEMENT](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/05/29/arts/pride-events-nyc.html#after-story-ad-1)

Your Pride Shows
----------------

The Brick Theater, a multidisciplinary performing arts space in Brooklyn, is hosting several queer-themed shows through June. Among them are [T4T Fest](https://www.bricktheater.com/event/t4t-fest-by-trans-artists-for-trans-audiences/2025-06-03/) (June 3-8), a series of plays “by trans artists, for trans audiences,” and the ninth annual [Queer Butoh Festival](https://www.bricktheater.com/event/queer-butoh-2025/2025-06-25/) (June 25-28), ​​featuring performers from Britain, Mexico and other countries.

[Broadway Bares](https://broadwaycares.org/pre-event/broadway-bares-2025), the long-running strip-and-sing benefit for Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS, is back with two performances at the Hammerstein Ballroom in Midtown (June 22). The theme is the Wizard of Oz-inspired “Come Out, Come Out”; the “Stripper Spectacular” package includes an invitation to a private cocktail party hosted by the Tony Award-winning director and choreographer Jerry Mitchell**.**

[Subscribe to The Times](https://www.nytimes.com/subscription?campaignId=8WXW7) to read as many articles as you like.

A version of this article appears in print on May 30, 2025, Section C, Page 11 of the New York edition with the headline: It’s Time to Step Out and Join the Celebrations.
